body:
<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* #18857 (build: avoid repetitions when enabling warnings in configure.ac by vasild)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.
Concept ACK. If we can do without compiler-specific extensions we should.
Concept ACK 👍

Here's a set of changes to remove the `Wgnu-zero-variadic-macro-arguments` cases:
https://github.com/fanquake/bitcoin/compare/no_gnu_extensions...Empact:2020-02-no_gnu_extensions

> Here's a set of changes

Thanks, I've taken some of those changes.
Concept ACK, this was for sure the intent of [noext].
Concept ACK -- inside the standard is better than outside the standard
Rebased on master now that #18087 is in, fixed up the sanitizer issue in prevector (bad rebase) and re-ordered some commits.
ACK 6af7c41771c2b3adeffe81ce06a70e0dbbef5360 -- diff looks correct

Isn't `__COUNTER__` a GNU extension too?
https://renenyffenegger.ch/notes/development/languages/C-C-plus-plus/preprocessor/macros/predefined/__COUNTER__
https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/cpp/Common-Predefined-Macros.html

saw it here again: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18234/commits/3cb26649716b2460dae44404f7ce2bd4715e0646#diff-998357bc40c89d644815a6fd52c99c9fR213

We can probably replace all usages of `__COUNTER__` with a combination of `__FILE__` and `__LINE__`

> Isn't __COUNTER__ a GNU extension too?

From what I can find, yes `__COUNTER__` (added to GCC in [4.3](https://gcc.gnu.org/gcc-4.3/changes.html)) is an extension, however it's supported by [GCC](https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/cpp/Common-Predefined-Macros.html),  [Clang](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/LanguageExtensions.html), [MSVC](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/preprocessor/predefined-macros?view=vs-2019) and `-Wgnu` doesn't currently warn about it. Maybe someone can address this in a followup if they'd like.

I've reverted the changes in [`logging.h`](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18088#discussion_r377616141) and did some testing to check that the "FlushStateToDisk: write coins cache to disk" call was always being logged, regardless of logging categories/options.
Rebased after #18591.

utACK 0ae8f18df

If we currently do not see any warnings due to the newly introduced `-Wgnu` then I would suggest to also add `-Werror=gnu` (if compiling with `--enable-werror`). So that a newly introduced warning in the future does not sneak - printed, but unnoticed in CI logs.

ACK 0ae8f18dfe143051fec6ae10ea7df10142e3ff2f

-----

Read relevant gcc docs, built, and ran tests.

ACK 0ae8f18dfe143051fec6ae10ea7df10142e3ff2f -- diff looks correct

Agree with @vasild about `-Werror=gnu` as part of `--enable-werror`. May also be done in a follow-up.
ACK 0ae8f18dfe143051fec6ae10ea7df10142e3ff2f
@vasild Would you mind taking on the `-Werror=gnu` thing? :)

> @vasild Would you mind taking on the `-Werror=gnu` thing? :)

Here it is: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/18887 build: enable -Werror=gnu

diff_hunk:
@@ -178,7 +178,7 @@ static inline void LogPrintf(const char* fmt, const Args&... args)
 // evaluating arguments when logging for the category is not enabled.
 #define LogPrint(category, ...)              \
     do {                                     \
-        if (LogAcceptCategory((category))) { \
+        if ((category) == BCLog::LogFlags::ALL || LogAcceptCategory((category))) { \
body: Why is this change needed?

diff_hunk:
@@ -178,7 +178,7 @@ static inline void LogPrintf(const char* fmt, const Args&... args)
 // evaluating arguments when logging for the category is not enabled.
 #define LogPrint(category, ...)              \
     do {                                     \
-        if (LogAcceptCategory((category))) { \
+        if ((category) == BCLog::LogFlags::ALL || LogAcceptCategory((category))) { \
body: Added this to ensure the FlushStateToDisk call would be logged even if no categories were active, which I believe is consistent with the current behavior - though I am not certain it is necessary.

diff_hunk:
@@ -178,7 +178,7 @@ static inline void LogPrintf(const char* fmt, const Args&... args)
 // evaluating arguments when logging for the category is not enabled.
 #define LogPrint(category, ...)              \
     do {                                     \
-        if (LogAcceptCategory((category))) { \
+        if ((category) == BCLog::LogFlags::ALL || LogAcceptCategory((category))) { \

@@ -178,7 +178,7 @@ static inline void LogPrintf(const char* fmt, const Args&... args)
 // evaluating arguments when logging for the category is not enabled.
 #define LogPrint(category, ...)              \
     do {                                     \
-        if (LogAcceptCategory((category))) { \
+        if ((category) == BCLog::LogFlags::ALL || LogAcceptCategory((category))) { \
body: I've removed this change.

I don't really like leaking this private implementation detail of the log flags into the caller code. I'd slightly prefer a type-safe way, that also better documents what is happening.

What about making this argument optional not with VA_ARGS, but with an `Optional<BCLog::LogFlags>`? Passing a nullopt or `{}` will unconditionally log, whereas passing a log flag will only log to that category (if enabled).

We could drop it altogether as this is the only call to `LOG_TIME_SECONDS`:

```diff
diff --git a/src/logging.h b/src/logging.h
index 5d8ec33392..b2fde1b9ea 100644
--- a/src/logging.h
+++ b/src/logging.h
@@ -178,7 +178,7 @@ static inline void LogPrintf(const char* fmt, const Args&... args)
 // evaluating arguments when logging for the category is not enabled.
 #define LogPrint(category, ...)              \
     do {                                     \
-        if ((category) == BCLog::LogFlags::ALL || LogAcceptCategory((category))) { \
+        if (LogAcceptCategory((category))) { \
             LogPrintf(__VA_ARGS__);          \
         }                                    \
     } while (0)
diff --git a/src/logging/timer.h b/src/logging/timer.h
index 34a6e25185..6a40dc48ba 100644
--- a/src/logging/timer.h
+++ b/src/logging/timer.h
@@ -95,8 +95,8 @@ private:
 
 #define LOG_TIME_MILLIS(end_msg, log_category) \
     BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::milliseconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg, log_category)
-#define LOG_TIME_SECONDS(end_msg, log_category) \
-    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::seconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg, log_category)
+#define LOG_TIME_SECONDS(end_msg) \
+    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::seconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg)
 
 
 #endif // BITCOIN_LOGGING_TIMER_H
diff --git a/src/validation.cpp b/src/validation.cpp
index a0ac003029..bab04b8e34 100644
--- a/src/validation.cpp
+++ b/src/validation.cpp
@@ -2328,7 +2328,7 @@ bool CChainState::FlushStateToDisk(
         // Flush best chain related state. This can only be done if the blocks / block index write was also done.
         if (fDoFullFlush && !CoinsTip().GetBestBlock().IsNull()) {
             LOG_TIME_SECONDS(strprintf("write coins cache to disk (%d coins, %.2fkB)",
-                coins_count, coins_mem_usage / 1000), BCLog::ALL);
+                coins_count, coins_mem_usage / 1000));
 
             // Typical Coin structures on disk are around 48 bytes in size.
             // Pushing a new one to the database can cause it to be written
```
Updated this branch: https://github.com/fanquake/bitcoin/compare/no_gnu_extensions...Empact:2020-02-no_gnu_extensions

> We could drop it altogether

I've updated to do this.

diff_hunk:
@@ -93,12 +93,10 @@ class Timer
 } // namespace BCLog
 
 
-#define LOG_TIME_MICROS(end_msg, ...) \
-    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::microseconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg, ## __VA_ARGS__)
-#define LOG_TIME_MILLIS(end_msg, ...) \
-    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::milliseconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg, ## __VA_ARGS__)
-#define LOG_TIME_SECONDS(end_msg, ...) \
-    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::seconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg, ## __VA_ARGS__)
+#define LOG_TIME_MILLIS(end_msg, log_category) \
+    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::milliseconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg, log_category)
+#define LOG_TIME_SECONDS(end_msg) \
+    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::seconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg)
body: So while the macro name indicates the only difference is the precision, they are functionally also different to the logging behaviour: One always logs, the other must accept a category. Not sure if it makes sense to keep the names so similar then.

diff_hunk:
@@ -93,12 +93,10 @@ class Timer
 } // namespace BCLog
 
 
-#define LOG_TIME_MICROS(end_msg, ...) \
-    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::microseconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg, ## __VA_ARGS__)
-#define LOG_TIME_MILLIS(end_msg, ...) \
-    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::milliseconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg, ## __VA_ARGS__)
-#define LOG_TIME_SECONDS(end_msg, ...) \
-    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::seconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg, ## __VA_ARGS__)
+#define LOG_TIME_MILLIS(end_msg, log_category) \
+    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::milliseconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg, log_category)
+#define LOG_TIME_SECONDS(end_msg) \
+    BCLog::Timer<std::chrono::seconds> PASTE2(logging_timer, __COUNTER__)(__func__, end_msg)
body: Ok. I've renamed `LOG_TIME_MILLIS` to `LOG_TIME_MILLIS_WITH_CATEGORY`.
